New York Mayor Eric Adams isn‚Äôt letting the bell ring on any legal consequences for the brawl inside Madison Square Garden at UFC 322 earlier this month.¬†

‚ÄúThese assaults at Madison Square Garden are completely unacceptable,‚Äù Adams wrote on X. ‚ÄúThe NYPD is already conducting a full investigation, and everyone responsible will be held accountable.‚Äù

The massive brawl broke out on the floor of the Garden as uniformed NYPD officers and event security attempted to intervene amid the chaos.¬†

item.description:
Dial F for Finished.

The city Department of Education wants to phase out the thousands of archaic landlines at its 1,800 schools and is set to seek bids from companies to install a strictly online system.

‚ÄúAs our schools, city, and world evolves, we are in the infancy stages of evaluating telecommunications alternatives that would significantly reduce our reliance on traditional landlines,‚Äù a DOE rep said.

‚ÄúThis effort, which focuses on resiliency and reliability, would build a system to withstand disruptions and shorten service restorations should they occur,‚Äù the representative said.

The DOE sent out an information request to potential bidders, a precursor for an official bid for a new telecommunications system.

The public notice reviewed by The Post said the DOE is looking to ‚Äútransition from aging digital PBX [Private Branch Exchange] systems to a unified, resilient, and cost-effective VOI [Voice over Internet Protocol] ecosystem ‚Ä¶ to replace NYC DOE‚Äôs legacy telephony systems across over 1,800 school and administrative sites.‚Äù

DOE officials declined to specify the costs of such an overhaul or how many landlines would be replaced. But it would clearly be a massive undertaking.

The new telecommunication system must support 150,000 staffers in 1,800 schools serving 900,000 students, as well as outreach to parents, meaning multilingual features would have to be part of any plan.

The telecom overhaul would likely take place under Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs administration.

The move comes as New York schools banned use of personal cell phones during class periods, an edict approved by Gov. Kathy Hochul.

Rep. Elise Stefanik issued a challenge to rival Gov. Kathy Hochul Tuesday over a member of Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs transition team who has voiced support for infamous cop killers.

Black Nationalist Lumumba Bandele was picked to serve on the incoming mayor‚Äôs Committee on Community Organizing on Monday despite previously aligning with Black Liberation Army members convicted of killing police officers in the tristate area.

Stefanik, a Republican looking to run against Hochul in next year‚Äôs election, quickly blasted the decision and called on Democratic Gov. Kathy Hochul to pressure Mamdani to push Bandele aside. ¬†

‚ÄúKathy Hochul‚Äôs endorsed Mayor-elect, Zohran Mamdani, just picked a man who supports the killers of cops in New York and New Jersey to serve on his transition team,‚Äù she said in a statement to The Post.

item.description:
Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy ruffled some feathers when he pleaded with US air travelers to smarten up their wardrobes when flying the friendly skies, but he also found some kindred spirits among passengers at New York-area airports.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs great advice, because when you feel good about how you look, you‚Äôre treated better and you treat people better,‚Äù traveler Tamaya Garcia, 48, said, agreeing with Duffy who begged travelers on Monday from Newark Liberty International Airport, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs try not to wear slippers and pajamas as we come here.‚Äù

Garcia got the memo ‚Äî she was decked out in a stylish wool tan coat, white body suit, tan cashmere pants and Nike sneakers while jetting into of JFK Airport in Queens.

For many passengers, throwing on the comfiest clothes in their wardrobe is a must for modern-day plane travel. But others still long for the bygone days of jet-setting around dressed to the nines like Don Draper.

‚ÄúI always have my makeup on, always have a cute outfit on. I always make sure my hair is clean and done,‚Äù said Garcia, a San Francisco resident who traveled to New York to spend Thanksgiving with her 20-year-old college student son.

She even said she refused to let her 16-year-old daughter get on a plane back home to California looking sloppy.

‚ÄúShe wanted to go to the airport without her hair washed, no make-up, literal pajama pants, and a hooded pullover. And I said, ‚ÄòNo, absolutely not!'‚Äù

Duffy also found a sartorial ally in Melanie Cox, 21, a senior at the University of Toledo who flew into Newark Liberty International Airport from Michigan to celebrate the holidays with her Big Apple friends.

‚ÄúPeople should dress up for the airport, it‚Äôs fun. I like waking up early, getting myself ready. It‚Äôs a long day and I like to feel put together ‚Äî and you really never know who you‚Äôre going to meet,‚Äù she said, sporting a matching set from White Fox.

Kim and Tommy Scarpati from Monmouth County, New Jersey, had their two young daughters, Nia and Evie, in tow for their voyage, mom and kids wearing matching hot-pink attire with their initials ironed onto their sweatshirts.

Kim also agreed with Duffy‚Äôs sentiment on slovenly flyers, saying, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not moving into the airport,‚Äù and even going so far as to say she would be wearing a dress if not for the ‚Äútactical clothing‚Äù needed for traveling with youngsters.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a girly girl,‚Äù she told The Post, adding she likes to feel ‚Äúfeminine and pretty‚Äù on her flights.

The matching neon clothing has the additional benefit of making her kids easy to spot in a crowd, allowing for ‚Äúsafety and ease‚Äù on travel days.

Another traveler, who gave her name only as Elizabeth, had on white pants and a tan sweater as she was about take off to Florida with her family for Thanksgiving.

‚ÄúI always dress like this. My father used to only fly with a jacket,‚Äù she said.

She agreed when asked whether her father‚Äôs high-flying fashion choices rubbed off on her, but added, ‚ÄúI like not to leave the house looking like I‚Äôm in my pajamas.‚Äù

Even during a long and uncomfortable flight, she said, ‚ÄúI still make an effort to look good and be coordinated.‚Äù

Jillian Carter, 32, from Brooklyn, was dressed in all black on her way from JFK to Atlanta to see family for Thanksgiving, clad in dress pants, a blouse and leather jacket ‚Äî and even silver-colored sneakers.

‚ÄúMy mom told me it‚Äôs important to look your best when you‚Äôre out and about, especially at the airport,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúYou never know who you‚Äôre gonna see, who you‚Äôre gonna meet ‚Äî comfy is my go-to, it doesn‚Äôt hurt to put a little effort into it.‚Äù

Other passengers, however, strongly disagreed with Duffy‚Äôs call to make air travel spiffy again.

Mashenka ‚ÄúDip‚Äù Clapp, 28, said the secretary needs to ‚Äútouch grass‚Äù and that he‚Äôs ‚Äúlost the plot‚Äù with his suggestion.

‚ÄúHe needs to mind his own business and let people be comfortable and find their own right way to do things that work for them and their lifestyle,‚Äù she said, adding that, ‚ÄúIf people have long international flights where they‚Äôre going to be sleeping the whole time, wouldn‚Äôt it be logical to be wearing PJs?‚Äù

Clapp was especially grateful for her comfortable choice of wardrobe after missing her Tuesday morning flight on her way back from New York to Savannah, Georgia, saying she‚Äôs planning to ‚Äúbum it out‚Äù at Newark Airport for the rest of the day and night.

‚ÄúPlus, who cares? Who are you trying to impress? The guards? The other travelers? The person who gives your boarding pass? They don‚Äôt care.‚Äù

Prince Green, on his way to the Dominican Republic where he runs a coffee shop, was wearing a black t-shirt, a maroon-colored hoodie, gray sweatpants and black socks and slippers. He said he had no hang-ups whatsoever about his clothing choices.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy with the way I look. It‚Äôs super comfortable. I don‚Äôt have to take my belt off, untie my shoes ‚Äî it‚Äôs vey quick and comfortable,‚Äù he said, describing himself as a ‚Äúsimple guy.‚Äù

As for Duffy‚Äôs entreaty, he said, ‚Äúhe has his opinion on how things should be, and I respect that. But I have mine, too. This is how I usually travel, simple and light ‚Äî got some shorts, some t-shirts,‚Äù he said as he walked off with his backpack slung over one shoulder.

Even though Garcia agreed with Duffy‚Äôs point, she said it‚Äôs unfortunate that looking put together at the airport doesn‚Äôt come naturally to many.

‚ÄúI think we should be civil on our own accord. We shouldn‚Äôt have someone tell us that. I think that‚Äôs just basic respect and cleanliness,‚Äù she said, but conceded that putting some extra thought into her traveling wardrobe could pay unexpected dividends.

‚ÄúI told my daughter, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm a single mom. I might meet my husband on a plane,‚Äù she said with a laugh.¬†

NYPD cop Joseph An had an unexpected pair of fans show up as he and 124 other Finest were promoted to sergeant Tuesday.

Brooklyn couple Sasha Cheng, 37, and her 39-year-old husband, Daniel Cheng, surprised the officer, 28, with a bouquet of flower to mark his promotion ‚Äî one year after the cop jumped into action and got them to the hospital to save the life of their then-unborn baby.

‚ÄúIt was a breached baby,‚Äù Sasha recalled to The Post. ‚ÄúIt definitely would have been life-threatening for both the baby and myself had Sgt. An not been there at the time. It was through divine intervention.‚Äù

Their son Royce Cheng is now a healthy 1-year-old.

The Chengs, who live in Bath Beach, were driving to New York Presbyterian Hospital in Lower Manhattan for Sasha to deliver Royce when they got stuck in traffic.

‚ÄúI think it was like 30, 40 more minutes more before we could get there ourselves,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe actually saw Officer An‚Äôs vehicle, and we pulled over next to him.‚Äù

She said she begged him, ‚ÄúCan you please help us get to the hospital safely? I‚Äôm in a lot of pain.

‚ÄúSgt. An made a call, and he escorted us to the hospital, and the staff were waiting for us, and the baby was born safely within 20 minutes of arrival.‚Äù

For the newly anointed sergeant, it was just another day on the job.

‚ÄúI just wanted to make sure that I was able to get them to the hospital safely and make sure that everything was OK safely and quickly,‚Äù he said humbly. ‚ÄúAnd, you know, I‚Äôm just very grateful to be able to help in that situation.‚Äù

The cop, who is set to marry his fianc√©e, Ashley Kim, next year, said he was grateful his hard work now has him wearing sergeant stripes.

‚ÄúYou know, I‚Äôve worked hard, and I‚Äôm very grateful to be given the opportunity to become a supervisor and basically inspire the minds of cops that I‚Äôm going to be supervising,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI had a lot of great mentors, and I want to become a great mentor to the cops that I work with.‚Äù

As far as the Chengs are concerned, he‚Äôs off to a good start.

A former bodega clerk will face trial for a third time on charges he abducted and murdered little Etan Patz ‚Äî whose 1979 disappearance shocked the country, prosecutors said Tuesday.

Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg‚Äôs office said that it‚Äôs ‚Äúprepared to proceed‚Äù to go to trial against Pedro Hernandez, 64, who confessed to killing the boy but whose 2017 murder conviction was overturned by an appeals court in July.

‚ÄúAfter thorough review, the district attorney has determined that the available, admissible evidence supports prosecuting‚Äù Hernandez on murder and kidnapping charges, Assistant District Attorney Sarah Marquez wrote in a letter filed in Manhattan Supreme Court.

Jury selection in the new trial needs to start by June 1, or Hernandez will be released from an upstate New York prison, according to federal court rulings.

A third trial would be the latest chapter in a saga that baffled the nation for decades after Patz vanished from a SoHo street on May 25, 1979 ‚Äî the first time he was allowed to walk to the bus stop alone.

Hernandez only became a suspect until 2012, when cops received a tip that he‚Äôd confessed during a prayer group to killing a child in New York.

He later made a¬†chilling videotaped confession¬†to fatally strangling the 6-year-old after luring him into the bodega basement with a promise of a soda.

Patz‚Äôs body was never recovered, and no physical evidence ever tied Hernandez to the murder.

A first trial ended in a hung jury in 2015.

Hernandez‚Äôs lawyers insist that he‚Äôs an innocent man, and that his confessions to the heinous crime were caused by delusions he suffered as part of a mental illness.

‚ÄúWe are deeply disappointed in the decision by the New York County District Attorney to retry Pedro Hernandez for a third time,‚Äù defense attorney Harvey Fishbein told The Post on Tuesday.

‚ÄúBut if this 46-year-old case is actually to be retried,‚Äù Fishbein added, ‚ÄúWe will be ready.‚Äù

The DA‚Äôs office has separately urged the US Supreme Court to reinstate Hernandez‚Äôs 2017 conviction after a midlevel appeals court found that the trial judge had instructed the jury improperly.

Bragg‚Äôs office had assigned a new group of prosecutors in recent months to reach out to witnesses and determine if bringing the case to trial for a third time was feasible.

A Republican looking to run against Rep. Tom Suozzi unloaded on the increasingly wealthy congressman with a sarcastic ‚ÄúSavant‚Äù honor for seeing his investment portfolio skyrocket 450%.

GOP hopeful Greg Hach said Suozzi should earn a special title because his $2.8 million fortune has ballooned to nearly $13 million during his seven years in the House of Representatives.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs miraculous. Truly. That‚Äôs a 450% leap!,‚Äù Hach said, saying his investments have outperformed billionaire investor Warren Buffett over the same stretch.

‚ÄúWith that rate of return, Taxman Tom could halve the federal deficit in a decade. Just remarkable!.‚Äù

Suozzi‚Äôs 2024 financial disclosure report filed in May shows he has investments in commercial real estate, a bio-start-up company, a Southampton Country Day Camp, treasury bills, a Merrill Lynch discretionary tax deferred account ‚Äî and a Suozzi Family Trust.

Hach ‚Äî an Air Force veteran and lawyer seeking to run against Suozzi in next year‚Äôs election ‚Äî sarcastically said ‚Äúour financial prayers have been answered.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe all know that Mr. Suozzi would never use insider knowledge from his position in Congress. That would be ghastly,‚Äù Hach quipped. ‚ÄúMr. Suozzi is simply the Mozart of mutual funds, the Shakespeare of shares, the Einstein of equities. It‚Äôs only logical that he should be named ‚ÄòU.S. Stock Savant.‚Äô‚Äù

Suozzi has come under fire in the past for not filing stock transactions and other investments in a timely manner, in violation of the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge Act, or STOCK Act.

Under current public disclosure rules set by the STOCK Act, members of Congress are required to disclose financial transactions in excess of $1,000 within a month and are prohibited from taking longer than 45 days to do so.

Hach mockingly said Suozzi should share his stock-picking genius with the next generation ‚Äî teenagers in House District 3, which covers communities in Nassau County and Queen

‚ÄúWith results like his, it would be negligent not to get him into the classroom,‚Äù Hach said.

‚ÄúKids need algebra, sure, but they also need to learn the difference between ordinary investing and whatever witchcraft Taxman Tom‚Äôs conjuring.‚Äù

Hach said he keeps his investments in a blind trust and he‚Äôll continue to do so if elected.

A Suozzi campaign rep ripped Hach‚Äôs obsession with the congressman‚Äôs investment portfolio.

‚ÄúVoters are sick of political games,‚Äù Suozzi‚Äôs senior campaign adviser Kim Devlin said. ‚ÄúAn inaccurate and uninformed reading of public disclosure reports won‚Äôt distract from Congressman Suozzi‚Äôs focus on bipartisan legislation to make health care less expensive, to fix immigration and the border, and to make things more affordable,‚Äù

She also said Suozzi supports ‚Äúbipartisan legislation making its way through Congress right now to ban members of Congress from owning individual stocks.‚Äù

Suozzi, a former Nassau County executive, served in Congress from 2017 to 2022 but gave up his House seat and ran for governor in 2022, losing in the Democratic Party primary to Gov. Kathy Hochul.

He reclaimed his former seat last year in a special election after convicted ex-Rep. George Santos (R) got the boot. He then won election again in November, narrowly defeating former Long Island Assemblyman Michael Li Petri.

Last week, Hach ripped Suozzi for proposing a federal income tax hike for earners making more than $400,000, giving him the nickname ‚ÄúTaxman Tom.‚Äù

Chung, a 34-year-old designer-loving wannabe influencer, has had the cops called on her at least 10 times since the end of last month for allegedly dining and trying to dash without paying.

Friday was her eighth arrest: this time for allegedly stealing $149 in food and refusing to pay at trendy Mexican restaurant Mole Bar and Grill in Williamsburg, according to Brooklyn prosecutors.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs been released onto supervised release and warned not to re-offend, and she keeps doing the same thing,‚Äù Rossman said, adding that prosecutors were seeking bail on the typically no-bail theft-of-services crime after she allegedly kept committing it.

To hear veteran NYPD Det. Thomas Cerbone tell it, a recent 9/11-linked kidney cancer diagnosis was ‚Äújust a bump in the road‚Äù of a proud 42-year legacy as one of New York‚Äôs Finest.

Cerbone, 62, a motorcycle cop and the senior active uniformed member on the force, did more than serve the community ‚Äî he changed the lives of some of the Big Apple‚Äôs most vulnerable children.

It‚Äôs been 12 years since he founded the annual Santa Day at the Seton Foundation for Learning, a Staten Island school for kids with special needs. And the tradition continues to this day.

‚ÄúWhen I was put up for detective, there were 10 officers up and only one from Highway 5, and I got it,‚Äù he told The Post. ‚ÄúWhen that happened I said I got to pay this forward. I got to do something to give back. And I went to go see if we could do something with the school.

‚ÄúIt was like I was supposed to go in there and do this,‚Äù Cerbone said. ‚ÄúAnd it works. Santa rides in the van the motorcycles are like the Reindeer and the kids go crazy. It makes their whole holiday season.‚Äù

On Tuesday, he received a traditional ‚Äúwalk out‚Äù at Highway 5 headquarters on Staten Island with his wife, Lori Ann Cerbone and their 27-year-old daughter, Chrissta, at his side.

Raised in Brooklyn, Cerbone is the son of an NYPD detective and the brother who served as a city correction officer before passing away several years ago.

He joined the NYPD in January 1984, and was assigned to the Midtown North Precint one year later.

In October 1995 he joined Highway 2 after completing wheel school, and moved to Highway 5 five years later. In 2005 he moved to the transportation unit before returning to the highway squad.

His service was rewarded in 2017 when he was promoted to second-grade detective, and again in November 2023 when he made first-grade.

Less than two years ago he was diagnosed with cancer, which has been tied to his service at Ground Zero following the September 11, 2001, terror attacks in Lower Manhattan.

It hasn‚Äôt dampened his love for the department, and now calls himself its number one recruiter.

‚ÄúEvery time I meet someone I sell this job,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm their number one recruiter. I‚Äôm always asking people did you take the NYPD test? I‚Äôm constantly recruiting.

‚ÄúSometimes it‚Äôs the people who look like they don‚Äôt really hold the NYPD in the highest regard I spend the most time talking to them,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúI tell them about my experience. I tell them about how they can give back, how they can help their communities get better and better.‚Äù

The veteran cop said he‚Äôs leaving the force grudgingly ‚Äî he said he‚Äôs only calling it a career because he‚Äôs about to hit mandatory retirement.

He said there‚Äôs only two things he‚Äôs looking forward to ‚Äî not having to set his alarm for 4:15 a.m., and, surprisingly, trading in his police motorcycle for a car after decades on two wheels.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm too old for it,‚Äù he quipped. ‚ÄúI need heat, AC, music.‚Äù

A student tourist whose left arm and left leg were severed when she fainted and tumbled in front of a Brooklyn subway train has landed a nearly $82 million jury verdict.

Luisa Janssen Harger Da Silva of Brazil was awarded the massive sum last week in Brooklyn federal court over her rail horror in 2016, when she was 21.

Da Silva was on a platform with her boyfriend when she fainted and fell onto the Atlantic Avenue tracks, where an oncoming train ran her over.

Nearly a decade later, a jury sided with her and her legal team in finding that the MTA failed to take the issue of people falling onto train tracks seriously.¬†

The woman‚Äôs suit argued the MTA had 15 years of data showing ‚Äúthat it was a moral certainty that innocent people, such as the plaintiff, would fall onto the tracks if the Authorities did not take steps to install platform edge safety devices.‚Äù

One of the plaintiff‚Äôs lawyer, David Roth, said, ‚ÄúThe failure to act in the face of a known, preventable hazard is the definition of negligence.‚Äù

The MTA has appealed the case, saying it ‚Äúdisagrees with the verdict,‚Äù rep Tim Minton said.

Last year, another man who lost an arm and leg when he drunkenly fell on the tracks and was hit by a subway train was initially awarded a staggering $90 million by a jury. The award was knocked down by a judge in June to just under $40 million.

At trial, internal MTA documents revealed that the transit agency was offered proposals to install platform doors at no cost as far back as 2011, with the idea being the company would make money by being allowed to offer advertising on the structures.

‚ÄúSeveral of those companies, the largest in the world, submitted detailed plans showing they could overcome every engineering challenge and install platform screen doors system-wide,‚Äù said another of Da Silva‚Äôs lawyers, Bob Genis.

One of the no-cost platform-door proposals from industry leader Faiveley Transit was called ‚Äúimpressive‚Äù by the MTA ‚Äúdue to the substantial amount of technical analysis into existing challenges with NYC Transit infrastructure.‚Äù

Yet no further study of platform barriers occurred between then and when Da Silva lost half of her appendages, Genis said, adding that the ‚ÄúMTA walked away‚Äù from the free offer.

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt speak to historical choices made decades ago,‚Äù Minton said in response, adding that the MTA has installed some type of platform barriers at 109 stations so far.

Minton said the agency claimed at trial that the offer and financing wasn‚Äôt confirmed at the time.

Costs aside, Minton said platform doors at a vast majority of stations wouldn‚Äôt work due to ‚Äúphysical feasibility and accessibility reasons.‚Äù

In 2012, the MTA weighed its annual litigation costs from train strikes as ‚Äúpart of an overview of the costs and benefits of platform edge doors.‚Äù

It found that its cost of litigation amounted to $7 million annually for the previous five years, according to emails surfaced by the same legal team in another lawsuit filed by a 2021 subway shove victim

Train strikes are rising, with 241 people hit by trains in 2023, according to MTA data reported by THE CITY.

The Long Island vigilante group behind the videotaped high-profile bust of an accused perverted elementary-school music teacher says it has yet to receive its owed $25,000-plus payout from YouTube.

Michael Villani, head of the Long Island Predator Poachers group that allegedly caught Wading River teacher Mark Verity in a sting in October, told The Post that YouTube deleted his account, which had more than 47,000 subscribers, just days before he was owed the large sum from ad revenue generated by his videos and separate donations made to his channel.¬†

‚ÄúOur account was terminated on Nov. 16, YouTube was supposed to put the money in our account on the 21st,‚Äù Villani said.¬†

Verity‚Äôs highly publicized outing and arrest generated more than $6,000 alone for the vigilante group off ads that YouTube included in Poachers‚Äô posted footage, Villani said. YouTube pays popular content creators a portion of the ad revenue it generates off such videos.

‚ÄúYouTube is actively preventing those who seek to protect kids from child predators and stealing from them as well as their supporters,‚Äù Villani told The Post.

A rep from YouTube defended the account‚Äôs deletion but did not respond to whether the group would be paid out the $25,500 it accrued from before the deletion or if refunds for the group‚Äôs donors would be issued.

‚ÄúThe channel in question was correctly terminated from YouTube for repeated violations of our Community Guidelines, which prohibit portraying in-person sting operations designed to accuse someone of egregious misconduct with a minor, without the presence of law enforcement,‚Äù the representative said.

Typically, YouTube operates on a three-strike system. Villani denied violating the rules multiple times and said the channel received just one strike a few days before the account was nuked.

He said the strike was for a short-form video that didn‚Äôt fully show the police presence in the camera despite them being there, which is required to be depicted for this type of content, according to YouTube‚Äôs terms of service.

After receiving the strike, the group deleted the video ‚Äî but just days later, their account was gone, followed by their appeal being denied and now the dough in limbo.

item.description:
Moms on Manhattan‚Äôs Upper East Side are embroiled in a Facebook feud over the mayoral election of Zohran Mamdani.

The private cyber scuffle spilled out into the pages of left-leaning New York magazine, which published a gossipy hit piece detailing how warring factions were battling it out on two private chat groups: Moms of the Upper East Side (MUES) and UES Mommas.

Barely were the ballots finally counted before hundreds of residents in the ritzy neighborhood ‚Äî¬†who voted for Andrew Cuomo by a 24-point margin ‚Äî posted panicked messages saying they were frightened and fleeing, fearing the Democratic socialist‚Äôs radical policies would turn the Big Apple into 1930s Germany.

‚ÄúWith all my love for NYC I can‚Äôt believe 50% +- of the city voted for this joker,‚Äù one mortified momma moaned on the MUES page, which has more than 35,000 members and is usually reserved for advice about nannies, strollers and schools.

‚ÄúWondering who‚Äôs actually leaving? To where, Florida?‚Äù they then asked.

More than 300 locals responded, per the report, claiming they were considering moving to New Jersey or Florida following Mamdani‚Äôs win.

Meanwhile, others on the pages proclaimed that the incoming mayor‚Äôs proposal for free buses would result in riders being raped and murdered.

However, users on both Facebook pages fought back, accusing their neighbors of being overwrought and Islamophobic.

‚ÄúIt IS racist to just be mad that your new mayor is a Muslim,‚Äù one member maintained.

Meanwhile, one mom named April, who is a member of MUES, told New York magazine that the complainers were all talk and actually had no plans to leave Manhattan.

‚ÄúNo, you‚Äôre not (moving),‚Äù she stated. ‚ÄúJust relax.‚Äù

The feuding between the two factions recently reached fever pitch, with the MUES group admins recently forced to instill a new rule for users.

‚ÄúYou may not attack or threaten other members while anonymous (or ever),‚Äù they implored.

Other more apolitical users urged calm, with one calling for all members to ‚Äúget a collective grip.‚Äù¬†

The article featured posts by Upper East Side resident Robyn Reiter, a doctor of physical therapy and a single mother of a 13-year-old son.

¬†‚ÄúWe are literally terrified that a mayor who won‚Äôt condemn Hamas and won‚Äôt condemn the phrase ‚ÄòGlobalize the Intifada‚Äô is now running the city with the second largest Jewish population in the world,‚Äù Reiter wrote on the MUES page.

‚ÄúIt feels very immoral to me at this moment to pay tax dollars to a city that just elected someone who would love to see my people murdered,‚Äù she told New York magazine directly in a follow-up interview. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all looking for an out, because I can‚Äôt jeopardize the safety of my son.‚Äù

She told the publication that she was considering leaving the Upper East Side and moving to Hoboken, New Jersey.

However, Reiter says she is disappointed with how she was portrayed in the article, telling The Post she found it inaccurate and reductive.

Reiter says she was forced to make her social media profiles private after the story came out ‚Äúbecause of all the hatred I was getting.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm maxed out on this topic already, unfortunately,‚Äù she told The Post. ‚ÄúInstead of being portrayed as a smart and hardworking Jewish woman who has every reason to worry about the safety of my Jewish son in today‚Äôs New York, the article portrayed me (and others) as hysterical rich women having meltdowns.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a single mother who works 10-hour days to support my son on my own,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúHe attends public school because I can‚Äôt afford private [school] without significant financial aid. I am neither a ‚Äòrich mom‚Äô nor ‚Äògoing to war.'‚Äù

MUES moderator Valerie Iovino echoed Reiter‚Äôs disappointment in how the group was portrayed, telling The Post that the piece ‚Äúreduced a group of 35,000+ diverse women ‚Äî a small fraction of which engaged in an important debate and conversation ‚Äî into caricatures based on their own stereotypes of Upper East Side women.‚Äù

‚ÄúMUES includes members with a wide range of political views, and a full spectrum of religious, socioeconomic, and racial backgrounds,‚Äù Iovino further stated. ‚ÄúYet they flattened the entire community into a two-dimensional image of Marie Antoinette clutching her pearls.‚Äù

In the wake of digital drama, many moms on the Upper East Side are reluctant to reveal their political persuasions publicly.

When The Post attempted to speak with one mom in the neighborhood, clad in a chic activewear outfit paired with a pair of large Gucci sunglasses and pushing a blanket-covered baby stroller, she quickly dismissed a request for comment.

Although she was cautious not to go on the record sharing her views, she did mutter under her breath, ‚ÄúI f‚Äîing hate that man‚Äù in reference to Mamdani as she scurried away.

She briefly told the reporter that she does not use Facebook and is not a member of either of the aforementioned online groups ‚Äî but clearly feels just as strongly as those online.

However, there are still some moms willing to go on record.

Samantha Ettus, a Jewish activist and mom of three, is not a member of either of the Facebook groups covered by New York magazine, but the native Upper East Sider aligns herself with those who believe Mamdani is not a good fit for the Big Apple.

‚ÄúFor many Jews that are paying attention, we see what‚Äôs going on and we see the patterns,‚Äù Ettus told The Post. ‚ÄúWe see how closely the environment for Jews across the world right now resembles the pre-World War II environment, and it‚Äôs a time where we can‚Äôt afford to make great mistakes.‚Äù

Meanwhile, Upper East Side moms aren‚Äôt the only ones finding themselves wrapped up in online exchanges regarding the new mayor.

On the adjacent Upper West Side ‚Äî long thought to be a liberal bastion ‚Äî one member of the UWS Mommas Facebook group was also advertising to locals looking to move out of New York.

Member Gitty Leiner said she knew of an excellent real estate agent for those considering moving to Florida. Others wanted to know more.

All appeared to go well after Li dropped JC off March 19 at the Hell‚Äôs Kitchen apartment Sultana shared with her boyfriend. But things quickly went south.

Sultana all but stopped answering Li‚Äôs check-in messages, which grew rapidly more concerned as several days passed, Li said.

After three days, Sultana finally shared blurry pictures of JC, including some showing him dirty and noticeably skinnier ‚Äî so much so that Li begged Sultana to allow a friend to stop by and check in on her beloved pet, Li said.

Sultana allegedly ignored the request, instead emphasizing that JC was happy and energetic, prompting Li to send a heartfelt text thanking Sultana for ‚Äútaking such good care of Jiacheng.‚Äù

Just 12 hours later ‚Äî the morning that Li was meant to pick up her beloved pet ‚Äî Sultana broke the news that JC was dead, Li said.

‚ÄúI was yelling on the plane, ‚ÄòThis is impossible!‚Äô I just couldn‚Äôt stop crying ‚Äî I can‚Äôt believe this happened ‚Äî everyone was looking at me,‚Äù Li said.

Sultana and her boyfriend ended up stuffing the dog‚Äôs body in a plastic bag and storing it in suitcase luggage that they hauled by taxi more than 2 miles away to a vet in Chelsea, with Sultana telling The Post it was only because the clinic around the corner from her home was too busy to help.

Li‚Äôs boyfriend, who was also out of town until that disastrous day, met them outside the office and took a video of the couple dragging the wheeled bag down the street.

Sultana told The Post, ‚Äú[JC‚Äôs] owners were well aware of how he was transported because I informed him before transporting JCs actual body.¬†

‚ÄúI was in disbelief, shock, and confusion on how to transport him. It was not my intent to disrespect JC at all,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI stated that I found JC unresponsive the next morning. That means he could have passed at any time between when I went to sleep and when I discovered him. Additionally, the owner did not reach the body for several hours due to her flight, which further explains the state of JCs body. No, I am not lying about when he was found unresponsive,‚Äù Sultana said.

Sultana and her boyfriend left without entering the vet, and Li‚Äôs beau, who doesn‚Äôt want to be named, carried the unopened luggage inside.

‚ÄúThere were about three, four dogs in the vet already, and as soon as I walked in, they started [whimpering] because they could feel [that JC was dead]. Even though I didn‚Äôt open the suitcase yet, they could feel it,‚Äù Li‚Äôs boyfriend recalled, saying that a rotten stench exuded from the bag.

‚ÄúThey had to light a couple candles because of the odor,‚Äù he said of the office. ‚ÄúThe nurse was the one that told us this first ‚Äî She‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòThey say your dog died this morning? There‚Äôs no way. There‚Äôs no way, how his body is conditioned.‚Äô ‚Äú

Li finally arrived at the vet and cried over JC‚Äôs body, according to a heartbreaking video circulating online.

The ‚Äútraumatized‚Äù pet owner ordered a necropsy to gain some insight into her dog‚Äôs death. The report said its results were inconclusive because of the ‚Äúdegree of autolysis‚Äù ‚Äî the first stage of decomposition.

The dog was suffering from muscle wasting, but the report said it couldn‚Äôt prove whether it was chronic or brought on by outside factors. JC did not appear to be poisoned, the preliminary report shows. The report excluded starvation as the source of the atrophy.

Without concrete evidence for JC‚Äôs death, Li said she has had little recourse to try to press charges but plans to bring a civil suit against Sultana.

‚ÄúHe means the whole world to me ‚Ä¶ He was with me all the time,‚Äù Li said of JC, pointing to a customized pillow of hers with the pup‚Äôs face on it.

‚ÄúI used to have a crate here for JC. For the first two months [after his death], I would carry this pillow and stay in the cage and just cry,‚Äù she said.

Li noted that JC was missing his red collar when he was dumped at the Chelsea vet‚Äôs office. She said that when she asked for it back, Sultana said she didn‚Äôt have it.

‚ÄúI did not remove his collar and had no reason to,‚Äù told The Post. ‚ÄúI thoroughly cleaned and searched my home and informed the owner that I did not have it. There is absolutely no advantage in my either removing or keeping his collar.‚Äù

Li said she has struggled for months to serve Sultana with court papers.¬†

The wannabe influencer dog sitter‚Äôs doorman barred Li‚Äôs boyfriend from walking up to the unit, and family members at another listed address for Sultana refused to open the door when cops arrived, the pair said.

But thanks to Chef Papa‚Äôs online outrage over Sultana‚Äôs visit, a battle¬†made viral by influencer Goob,¬†Li was finally able to get traction ‚Äî and plenty of attention ‚Äî on her horrifying dog case.

Sultana‚Äôs Rover account has since been deactivated, the pet-sitting app confirmed, telling The Post it had conducted an investigation but had little information because the stay was not booked on the platform.

‚ÄúOur hearts go out to Ms. Li as she mourns this devastating loss. We understand how distressing and painful Jiacheng‚Äôs passing must be, as many of us at Rover are pet parents ourselves,‚Äù a rep said.
